chapter.htmlHeader: Antimuscarinics (anticholinergics)
chapter.htmlStringContent: <!-- begin item cd05ac0b-e345-4ee6-a5ef-520b515fa82f --><!-- end item cd05ac0b-e345-4ee6-a5ef-520b515fa82f -->

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the contraindications and cautions for antimuscarinics?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe an antimuscarinic drug to people with:
    • Gastrointestinal obstruction or intestinal atony.
    • Myasthenia gravis.
    • Paralytic ileus.
    • Prostatic enlargement.
    • Pyloric stenosis.
    • Severe ulcerative colitis.
    • Significant bladder outflow obstruction or urinary retention.
    • Toxic megacolon.
    • Severe hepatic impairment — manufacturer advises caution for oxybutynin; flavoxate can be used.
  • In addition:
    • Do not prescribe solifenacin to people with narrow-angle glaucoma.
    • Do not prescribe flavoxate to people with gastro-intestinal haemorrhage.
    • Do not prescribe propiverine to people with:
      • Moderate to severe hepatic impairment.
      • Uncontrolled angle-closure glaucoma.
      • Tachyarrhythmias.
    • Do not prescribe trospium to people with tachyarrhythmias.
    • Avoid modified-release preparations of tolterodine in people with:
      • Hepatic impairment. 
      • Severe renal impairment (estimated glomerular filtration rate [eGFR] less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2). 
  • Prescribe an antimuscarinic drug with caution to:
    • People with:
      • Acute myocardial infarction.
      • Arrhythmias — may be worsened.
      • Autonomic neuropathy.
      • Cardiac insufficiency or cardiac surgery — due to association with tachycardia.
      • Conditions characterized by tachycardia.
      • Congestive heart failure or coronary artery disease — may be worsened.
      • Diarrhoea.
      • Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease.
      • Hiatus hernia with reflux oesophagitis.
      • Hypertension.
      • Hyperthyroidism — due to association with tachycardia.
      • Prostatic hyperplasia.
      • Pyrexia.
      • Ulcerative colitis.
      • Mild to moderate hepatic impairment — see the section on Doses for recommended dosage adjustments in people with hepatic impairment.
      • Renal impairment — use oxybutynin with caution; no dosage adjustment is needed with darifenacin and flavoxate; other antimuscarinics require dosage adjustment if the eGFR is less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2. See the section on Doses for recommended dosage adjustments in people with renal impairment.
    • Elderly people (especially if frail).
    • People susceptible to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • In addition:
    • Prescribe oxybutynin with caution in people with acute porphyrias.
    • Prescribe solifenacin with caution in people with:
      • Neurogenic bladder disorder.
      • Susceptibility to QT-interval prolongation.
    • Prescribe tolterodine with caution in people with history of QT-interval prolongation.

[BNF 76, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I start and titrate an antimuscarinic drug?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The recommended doses are:
    • Oxybutynin immediate-release preparations — initially 5 mg two to three times a day, increased if necessary up to 5 mg four times a day.
      • In elderly people, prescribe initially 2.5–3 mg twice daily, increased if tolerated to 5 mg twice daily, adjusted according to response.
      • Use with caution in renal and hepatic impairment.
    • Oxybutynin modified-release preparations — initially 5 mg once daily, increased in steps of 5 mg every week, adjusted according to response; maximum 20 mg a day.
      • Use with caution in renal and hepatic impairment.
    • Oxybutynin transdermal patch — one patch twice a week.
      • Patch is to be applied to clean, dry unbroken skin on abdomen, hip or buttock. Patch should be removed every 3–4 days and site replacement patch on a different area. The same area should be avoided for 7 days.
      • Use with caution in renal and hepatic impairment.
    • Darifenacin modified-release preparations — initially 7.5 mg once daily, increased if necessary to 15 mg after 2 weeks.
      • Prescribe a maximum of 7.5 mg daily in moderate hepatic impairment; avoid in severe hepatic impairment.
    • Fesoterodine modified-release preparations — 4 mg once daily, increased if necessary up to 8 mg once daily.
      • Increase dose cautiously in mild hepatic impairment; maximum daily dose of 4 mg in moderate hepatic impairment.
      • Increase dose cautiously in mild to moderate renal impairment (estimated glomerular filtration rate [eGFR] 30–80 mL/minute/1.73m2); maximum daily dose of 4 mg in severe renal impairment (eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2).
    • Flavoxate immediate-release preparations — 200 mg three times a day.
    • Propiverine immediate-release preparations (for urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence associated with overactive bladder) — 15 mg once or twice a day, increased if necessary up to 15 mg three times a day.
      • Use with caution in mild hepatic impairment; avoid in moderate to severe hepatic impairment.
      • Prescribe a maximum of 30 mg a day in severe renal impairment (eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2); use with caution in mild to moderate avoid in renal impairment (eGFR 30–80 mL/minute/1.73m2).
    • Propiverine modified-release preparations (for urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence associated with overactive bladder) — 30 mg once a day.
      • Use with caution in mild hepatic impairment; avoid in moderate to severe hepatic impairment.
      • Prescribe a maximum of 30 mg a day in severe renal impairment (eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2); use with caution in mild to moderate avoid in renal impairment (eGFR 30–80 mL/minute/1.73m2).
    • Solifenacin immediate-release preparations — 5 mg once daily, increased if necessary to 10 mg once daily.
      • Prescribe a maximum of 5 mg daily in moderate hepatic impairment; avoid in severe hepatic impairment.
      • Prescribe a maximum of 5 mg a day in severe renal impairment (eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2).
    • Tolterodine immediate-release preparations — 2 mg twice daily, reduced if not tolerated to 1 mg twice daily.
      • Reduce dose to 1 mg twice daily in hepatic impairment.
      • Reduce dose to 1 mg twice daily in severe renal impairment (eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2).
    • Tolterodine modified-release preparations — 4 mg once daily.
      • Avoid in hepatic impairment.
      • Avoid in severe renal impairment (eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2).
    • Trospium immediate-release preparations — 20 mg twice daily, to be taken before food.
      • Use with caution in mild to moderate hepatic impairment; avoid in severe hepatic impairment.
      • Reduce dose to 20 mg once daily or 20 mg on alternate days in severe renal impairment (eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73m2).
    • Trospium modified-release preparations — 60 mg once daily.
      • Use with caution in mild to moderate hepatic impairment; avoid in severe hepatic impairment.
      • Avoid Regurin® XL in renal impairment.
  • Review the person every 4–6 weeks until symptoms are stable, and then every 6–12 months. Assess symptoms, quality-of-life, adverse effects, and the need for continuing treatment.

 [BNF 76, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of antimuscarinics?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Adverse effects of antimuscarinics are common, and elderly or frail people may be more susceptible.
    • The impact of adverse effects can be reduced by using a small starting dose and titrating the dose slowly. See the section on Initiation and titration for more information.
    • If unacceptable adverse effects persist, reduce the dose or stop treatment with the antimuscarinic drug.
  • Adverse effects of antimuscarinic drugs include:
    • Common or very common — constipation, dizziness, drowsiness, dry mouth, dyspepsia, flushing, headache, nausea, palpitations, skin reactions, tachycardia, urinary disorders, vision disorders, and vomiting.
    • Rare or very rare — confusion (more common in elderly).
  • In addition for oxybutynin:
    • With oral use:
      • Common or very common — diarrhoea and dry eyes.
      • Uncommon — abdominal discomfort, appetite decreased, and dysphagia.
      • Frequency not known — angioedema, anxiety, arrhythmia, cognitive disorder, depressive symptom, drug dependence, gastrointestinal disorders, glaucoma, hallucination, heat stroke, hypohidrosis, mydriasis, nightmare, paranoia, photosensitivity reaction, seizure, and urinary tract infection (UTI).
    • With transdermal use:
      • Common or very common — gastrointestinal discomfort and increased risk of infection.
      • Uncommon — back pain and injury.
  • In addition for darifenacin:
    • Common or very common — abdominal pain, dry eye, and nasal dryness.
    • Uncommon — asthenia, bladder pain, cough, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, erectile dysfunction, flatulence, hyperhidrosis, hypertension, increased risk of infection, injury, insomnia, oedema, oral ulceration, taste altered, thinking abnormal, and urinary tract disorder.
    • Frequency not known — angioedema.
  • In addition for fesoterodine:
    • Common or very common — diarrhoea, dry eye, gastrointestinal discomfort, insomnia, and throat complaints.
    • Uncommon — altered taste, cough, fatigue, gastrointestinal disorders, nasal dryness, UTI, and vertigo.
    • Rare or very rare — angioedema.
  • In addition for propiverine:
    • Common or very common — abdominal pain and fatigue.
    • Uncommon — altered taste and tremor.
    • Rare or very rare — restlessness.
    • Frequency not known — hallucination.
  • In addition for solifenacin:
    • Common or very common — gastrointestinal discomfort.
    • Uncommon — altered taste, cystitis, dry eye, dry throat, fatigue, gastrointestinal disorders, nasal dryness, peripheral oedema, and UTI.
    • Rare or very rare — angioedema and hallucination.
    • Frequency not known — anaphylactic reaction, arrhythmias, decreased appetite, delirium, dysphonia, glaucoma, hyperkalaemia, liver disorder, muscle weakness, QT interval prolongation, and renal impairment.
  • In addition for tolterodine:
    • Common or very common — abdominal pain, bronchitis, chest pain, diarrhoea, dry eye, fatigue, gastrointestinal disorders, paraesthesia, peripheral oedema, vertigo, and weight gain.
    • Uncommon — arrhythmia, heart failure, memory loss, and nervousness.
    • Frequency not known — angioedema and hallucination.
  • In addition for trospium:
    • Common or very common — abdominal pain.
    • Uncommon — chest pain, diarrhoea, and flatulence.
    • Rare or very rare — arthralgia, asthenia, dyspnoea, and myalgia.
    • Frequency not known — agitation, anaphylactic reaction, angioedema, hallucination, and severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs).
  • In addition for flavoxate:
    • Frequency not known — angioedema, diarrhoea, dysphagia, eosinophilia, fatigue, hyperpyrexia, hypersensitivity, leucopenia, nervousness, and vertigo.

[BNF 76, 2018]​​​​​​

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions of antimuscarinics?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Drug interactions of antimuscarinics include [BNF 76, 2018]:
    • Other drugs with antimuscarinic action — concurrent use of antimuscarinic drugs with other drugs with antimuscarinic action (such as tricyclic antidepressants and sedating antihistamines) will cause additive adverse effects.
    • Antiarrhythmic drugs — tolterodine should not be given to people taking antiarrhythmic medication due to the increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias.
    • Potent CYP3A4 inhibitors — darifenacin, fesoterodine, solifenacin, and tolterodine are metabolized by the cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP3A4. For people also taking a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor (such as clarithromycin, itraconazole, or ritonavir):
      • Concurrent use with darifenacin is contraindicated.
      • Most manufacturers advise against concurrent use with tolterodine.
      • Manufacturers advise adjusting the dose of solifenacin and fesoterodine.
  • For a complete list of possible drug interactions of the individual antimuscarinic drug, see the electronic Medicines Compendium (eMC) or the British National Formulary (BNF).
